'''Lavelle White''' (born July 3, 1929) is an [[United States|American]] [[Texas blues]] and [[soul blues]] singer and songwriter. After performing most of her adult lifetime, White released three albums, the first of which was issued in 1994 when she was aged 65.

==Life and career==
White was born in [[Amite City, Louisiana]], [[United States]], the daughter of [[Sharecropping|sharecropper]] parents.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="MN">{{cite web |url=http://www.mnblues.com/profile/profile-lavelle.html |title=Lavelle White |author=Stiles, Ray M. |date= |work= |publisher=Mnblues.com |accessdate=December 22, 2011}}</ref> 

She started to write poetry at the age of 12, which led her to song writing,<ref name="AMG"/> and singing [[gospel music|gospel]] songs.<ref name="Austin"/>  White relocated to [[Houston]], [[Texas]], at the age of 15, and started to perform in that city's blues [[nightclub|clubs]] with the guitarist Clarence Hollimon.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="George">{{cite web |url=http://georgegraham.com/white.html |title=Miss Lavelle White: ''It Haven't Been Easy'' - by George Graham |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Georgegraham.com |accessdate=December 22, 2011}}</ref> Her break came when [[Johnny Copeland]] recommended her to [[Don Robey]], the owner of the [[Duke Records|Duke]] and [[Peacock Records|Peacock]] [[record label]]s.<ref name="AMG"/> She was then billed as 'Miss La-Vell'. White recorded fourteen tracks, released as a number of [[Single (music)|singles]] on Duke, between  1958 and 1964.<ref name="Wood"/>  These included "If I Could Be with You," "Just Look at You Fool," "Stop These Teardrops," and "The Tide of Love."  Several  of her songs were self penned, a process of writing that has lasted most of her lifetime.<ref name="AMG"/> Under the pseudonym of Deadric Malone, White also wrote [[Bobby Bland]]'s "Lead Me On", which was a hit in 1960.<ref name="George"/> She appeared in local revues up to the late 1960s.<ref name="Austin"/>

She toured across the United States when her [[recording contract]] expired.<ref name="AMG"/> In the 1960s White shared musical stages with many  musicians including Bland, [[Sam Cooke]], [[Otis Redding]], [[Junior Parker]], [[Aretha Franklin]] and [[Jerry Butler (singer)|Jerry Butler]].<ref name="George"/> White moved to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] in 1978, where she appeared at various clubs and worked with [[Junior Wells]], [[Lonnie Brooks]] and [[Buddy Guy]], before returning to Houston eight years later.<ref name="Pond">{{cite web |url=http://www.ponderosastomp.com/music_more/271/Lavelle+White |title=Lavelle White |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Ponderosastomp.com |accessdate=December 20, 2011}}</ref> White was later voted Houston's Blues Artist Of The Year.<ref name="MN"/>  She relocated again and became a regular performer around the [[Austin, Texas]] area, including a residency at [[Clifford Antone|Antone's]].<ref name="George"/>

However, her debut [[album]] was not released until 1994, when ''Miss Lavelle'' was issued on the Antone's label.  It was her first recording for almost 30 years.<ref name="AMG"/> White appeared at the [[San Francisco Blues Festival]] in 1995. She has also performed at the [[Houston International Festival]]. Her second album was ''It Haven't Been Easy'' (1997).<ref name="AMG"/> Both albums featured guitar work from her former performing colleague, Clarence Hollimon.<ref name="Wood">{{cite book
| first= Charles Roger
| last= Wood
| year= 2003
| title= Down in Houston: Bayou City blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[University of Texas Press]]
| location= Austin, Texas
| page= 218
| isbn= 0-292-79159-3}}</ref> The same year, White appeared with [[Delbert McClinton]] on the [[television program]], ''[[Austin City Limits]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1049227/ |title=Blues Night with Delbert McClinton and Miss Lavelle White |author= |date= |work= |publisher=IMDb.com |accessdate=December 22, 2011}}</ref> Her third album, ''Into the Mystic'', was released in 2003.<ref name="Albums"/>

She has been nominated several times for a [[Blues Music Award]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/od/bluesawards/a/2014-Blues-Music-Awards.htm |title=2014 Blues Music Awards Nominees and Winners |publisher=Blues.about.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}}</ref> and in 2006 was inducted into the Texas Music Hall of Fame.<ref name="Austin">{{cite news |url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/AMDB/Profile?oid=oid:57496 |title=Miss Lavelle White |author=Moser, Margaret |date= |work=[[The Austin Chronicle]] |publisher=Austinchronicle.com| accessdate=December 22, 2011}}</ref> The same year her ensemble was voted the Best Blues Band in ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' Music Awards.<ref name="Hudson">{{cite book
| first= Kathleen
| last= Hudson
| year= 2007
| title= Women in Texas music: stories and songs
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[University of Texas Press]]
| location= Austin, Texas
| page= 146
| isbn= 978-0-292-73467-8}}</ref>  

White recently appeared at the [[Ponderosa Stomp]] music festival.<ref name="Pond"/>
